I'd much rather walk a couple of extra blocks and give the really NICE and COOL guys on the corner of 9th and Judah my business, or go to Roxy where they're also cooler.  How can you maintain your business when everyone in the neighborhood thinks you suck?
author: Eviltwin X.

description: If you are in the neighorhood or have the time to visit, then a stop in to Amazing Sam's Golden Bear Market is a must. He has everything you need and the best coffee around!
author: Mycho C.

description: Taking a sip of Sam's Cup of Love Coffee is like slipping into a hot tub.  The comfort and pleasure wash over and you never want it to end.
author: Daniel F.

description: Great spot for Turkish coffee and breakfast. Outdoor seating on a sunny corner. Excellent selection of single malt scotch and other whiskeys and wines. Family run and friendly service.
author: Mark B.

description: I really don't understand the negative reviews, especially about Sam or the family that runs the business. I've been here multiple times since the remodel. Sam is always extremely friendly and pleasant. They make damn good sandwiches - in fact I'm eating one as we speak. These are hard working business owners and I've never been treated with anything but respect!
author: J M.

description: I was taking a break from studying at the parnassus library, and i didnt feel like walking all the way to starbucks, so what the heck why not try turkish coffee? I walked in and was greeted by the owner, who immediately informed me that he made the worlds best coffee ( oh yeah, he also said that he was a great singer and belly dancer....) Turns out the coffee was great... Freshly ground, brewed one cup at a time! Loved it! Will definitely be returning here for coffee during future study breaks
author: Erik A.

description: I went to buy and grind 2 pounds of coffee. It took a bit longer than expected but the grounds were so fine it was like flour.
author: Monica D.

description: this is by far the best cup of coffee i have ever had, mostly because it is made with such TLC.  the owner is hilarious and talks to you the whole time in between having you smell the beans before he grinds them fresh, then once after.  he tells you how he stirs the coffee as it brews to bring out all the flavor and he even sweetens and adds cream for you and never misses on flavor.  he also loves to watch you take your first sip...now that is someone who loves what they do and what they provide.  i can't wait until you can order the beans to ship somewhere, so i can share this amazing coffee with everyone i know
author: Kris B.

description:
I've lived in the neighborhood for almost 10 years and have seen this market go through alot of changes.  To me, it's the epitome of a great community store where the owner waves when you walk by and always has something interesting to say.   Sam is immediately personable, and you often find him smiling or dancing behind the cash register, or just talking with friends.  He's very genuine and brightens my mood whenever I run to the corner for cereal or beer.  He's proud of what he does and has made it a family business that I'm happy to support.  He shows me pictures of his kids on his phone now that he has gotten in the habit of texting.

The prices used to be out of sync with the quality of product (moldy bread, bad milk), but now it's much more in line.  Sam knew the problems and has much better groceries.   There are some great values on wine, and everything else is pretty much the proportional price you pay for 'convenience' of being a couple blocks away.  I'll go here any day over Andronico's.  I've been wanting to write a review for a while now, and finally did today after Sam made me laugh once again, AND I found a great deal on wine.  You don't always get that at Safeway.
author: sophie s.

description: Sam introduced us to a great blend that was tasty and used cream that didn't take away from the great taste.  Great coffee, great shop!  Sam is a part of the great experience.
author: Ayada B.

description: Great coffee and I am a purist about my brew. This guy knows how to make it right... individually brewed, dark and robust. Forget the chains. If you're in the Sunset, grab your morning Joe at 6th and Judah. You won't regret it.
author: Joyce H.

description:
I give the Golden Bear a 5+ stars, not just for it's delicious hand brewed coffee made drip by drip to perfection, but also for its authentic atmosphere and down to earth staff. Both times I went into the cafe, I received great service, totally non-bull shit and real. That is much to be appreciated, because you get the sense that you are actually seen, heard, and treated on an individual basis, rather than just herded through a line.  The owner is really cool and knows his customers names and what they drink. If he see's you walking down the sidewalk he'll probably have your drink order started before you get there! 

Other than great coffee there's freshly made sandwiches and a well stocked market.

Get in there! Prices for turkish and slow drip coffee is cheaper than philz (though I also love philz) and blue bottle!!
author: Abby f.

description: Awesome coffee. Owner is funny, cool, and quite friendly. Plus, they stock pork rinds, which is apparently a rarity in the Inner Sunset. I'm a fan.
author: Sergio P.

description:
Wow. I've had the exact opposite experience than a bunch of reviewers here -- and at least one of these reviews was really bigotted and I just don't understand this, but that's not why I'm writing.

The woman who runs this store is very kind and sweet.  What's wrong with that? I find it hard to believe she was actually mean. I really feel the love when I go in there.

The owner of the store is a straight-up good guy who goes out of his way to treat people right.  What's wrong with kindness meeting kindness?  It only brings more kindness.

I, for one, will continue going out of my way to patronize this store. They are really sweet -- you people should stop being so uptight.
author: InannaMouse M.

description:
FALAFEL FRUSTRATION!!!!!!

I must say Kai T. is spot on: "This place is where Seinfeld got the idea for his soup nazi I think." Except replace, soup with falafel. 

I'll just tell it like it went down: At 9:45pm at night I am leaving the gym and I walk in and see nobody in site. "Hello," I yell out. A man pops out reeking of alcohol and stands right in my face. I ask him how much the falafal was and how great it looked and tell him I didn't know they made this here. He starts blabbering that he has the best falafel and tells me "Take this home, and if you like it, I will give you all the falafal you want *free for one month." I knew this obviously had an asterik, *does not apply when man is drunk out of his mind. However, with a supposed change in ownership, and the fact that it was 10pm....it wasn't out of line to offer me a free one so that I would come back and get more.....BUT no --- the drunk man behind the counter changed his mind and told me I would pay for the falafel and got all rude with me. I am sorry but you don't get all sweet with me, offering me visions of free falafel (which would be good business sense, especially since it was so late at night) and then rudely change your mind. So I put the falafel on the counter in a huff, let out a gasp, and walked away entirely frustrated because the falafel looked good.

Thankfully you can get falafel at Yumma's on Irving and they are very nice. And you can go to a great corner store, Roxies on ninth, and they are wonderful and nice.

I hate to write bad reviews because I don't want to hurt people's business, but seriously, this was unprofessional and rude.
author: Sari G.

description: What a find!  They have an amazing selection of coffee from all over the world.  I had the organic Peru and it was one of the best cups of coffee I've had in years.  My son had the blueberry muffin and was quite satisfied.  Two thumbs up from the kid crowd.  My almond croissant was also delicious.  Thanks again for a great start to our day.
author: Margaret R.

description: We love to stay in this great area near UCSF Medical, the fabulous Sunset Area, and convenient transit. We discovered this fantastic coffee shop last year, but it has been completely renovated! It is bright and beautiful and you can get a completely handcrafted cup of coffee made to your taste (my favorite is the Ethiopian medium roast made sweet and milky.) No long lines for mass produced coffee, and the cost is only $3 for individually ground and dripped coffee.Sam and Kathy are sincere and thoughtful, which is why they can craft a delicious cup of coffee for each person! They have a nice pastry case with favorite as well as new-to-me goodies. My favorite treats are the delicious cinnamon rolls, baklava, and out of this world quiche! I ordered a dozen to take back to Hawaii as gifts for my friends. Sam had my order beautifully packed and boxed for easy transit. I am so excited about sharing this special treat with my friends... Who wants Sees Candies when they can have some delicious quiches instead? I will be back every time we come to our favorite City By The Bay! Oh... For those of you who enjoy your "spirits" Sam carries an impressive selection of domestic and imported wines and liquor too.
author: Donna N.

description: Extremely nice man running the shop! Turkish coffee is fabulous!  Never knew this place was here. I was told I "must go." It was worth the pain of looking for parking. The coffee is strong and is served with cream and sugar if you like. Similar to Philz.  I have also heard the tea is great, will have to try next time!
author: Joanna W.

description: Great neighborhood store, I'm constantly impressed by how hard they work to keep their customers happy, pretty genuine folks.  Great selection for its size, too--I can almost always find whatever random thing I go in for.  Plus there's usually other random stuff you wouldn't really expect them to have too--i.e., I had a falafel sandwich for dinner tonight that I bought last minute at their counter-- total surprise, best falafel I've ever had in SF, no question, and it's not at all what I'd expect to taste from something I get off a corner store counter... just a well done little store.
author: Brad H.

description: Sam is a fantastic guy. While his exterior seems hardened the man has a heart of gold. As a newcomers to the city, Sam was extremely welcoming, offering suggestions to local haunts and sights. His coffee, teas and hot chocolate are "made with love". Indeed they are- they are second to none, always fresh and handmade. You will "feel sorry for yourself" when you drink coffee elsewhere. When you visit this store, not only get to enjoy a fantastic brew, but you get to experience Sam. This man really should create a twitter account @shitsamsays
author: Janell S.

description:
FYI, recently this market changed owners.

I live up the street and come here when I need something simple, like some soap, some fresh fruit, or some eggs  The prices are about the same as other small markets in SF. The owner is friendly.  They are open late.  They always have some nice treats like Baklava, which I like.
author: Charles M.

description: Sam,the owner,  is quiet a character and nice. introduced us to his famous turkish coffee, which he gave for free just because he wanted to prove to us how good his coffee was. lots of talking, invited us to come back. if you like to talk to people, you will like buyin stuff here
author: Melissa W.

description: Sam makes the best coffee in sf!  I'm drinking it religiously almost everyday.  I used I be a big fan of philz coffee but it was little bit too far to drive.  So I decided to try Sam's cup of luv and I was hooked!  This Turkish coffee is lighter but full of flavors.  I don't know what he puts in there but it sure does taste amaziiiinnng!  Best coffee in sf!  Yelping at golden bear as I'm drinking this amazing cup of luv.
author: muti v.

description: I went there the other night for a bottle of wine, and the owner told me, "Have you tried our coffee? It's the best f-ing coffee in the world. Come back tomorrow and have some, if you don't believe me, I'll buy you lunch. Even people who don't drink coffee love my coffee." Intrigued, I decided I had no choice but to at least come back the following day and see if this was true or not.  I don't even like coffee, and let me tell you, this man was not lying.  His Turkish strong coffee made me a believer, and was just the push I needed to start my Saturday morning not being hungover.  I don't always drink coffee, but when I do, I prefer Golden Bear Market.
author: Giorgio L.

description:
I have reason to hate this market. 
Let me tell you the story of SAM and the market rearrangement. 
One afternoon I came in simply to buy some milk. Then, this man who introduced himeslf as Sam came up to me and asked if I could help move a few of the little metal shelves. I of course said, sure! So we moved these heavy ass shelves wiht like hella groceries on them. Then, he asked me to move more. and more. and more. and more. and more. We slowly rearranged the WHOLE FREAKING STORE. Being the submissive asian I am, I was hesitant to say anything because I was just in disbelief that SOMEONE WOULD ACTUALLY CON an innocent customer to do their dirty work. So after moving SEVERAL CASES OF WINE, the ODWALLA MACHINE and more shelves, I said... "UMM, yeah I need to go now". In the midst of all of this SAM would tell me "I LIKE YOU, TIM" "YOURE A GOOD MAN, TIM" and he'd also say some questionable things like "YOU KNOW TIM, ALL THESE WOMEN DO IS CREATE PROBLEMS" "WOMEN ARE USELESS." He said this as his wife, the lady that usually runs the market store was standing by.... awkward. 
So I think what happened was my dad called me and I said OMG HAVE TO GO BYE. SAM let me take something for free so I grabbed the closest thing to me, some big bottle of water and got the hell out of there. 
i didn't even get my milk! 

Anyways, another time, a couple friends and i went here to buy some tequila and limes. The sign for the 1800 was mismarked and we thought it was cheap, but then it wasn't and we were sad. and then she tried to sell us these like wrinkly lemons to pass off as limes. wtf. 

The owner lady is interesting... she tries to be friendly but it just makes me uncomfortable. I would come here more often to pick up groceries (not produce...) but I dont want to get con-ed into rearranging the grocery store again. And shit there is expensive.
author: Tim B.

description: I came here for the first time today, it was great, lots of different snacks, candies, liquor, and beer. I ended up getting the coffee because my bf came here for coffee one day and the owner Sam made him a special Turkish coffee. Turkish coffee rules. I saw the sandwich menu and hope that they are as amazing as the coffee. Also spotted some hookahs and wonder if they have like a bar type/rental thing.
author: Myfood Y.

description: It still one star but I do need to make one correction.   The gentleman that runs the place does not sit there naked however he does take his shirt off and is in his shorts sitting outside the corner.   I work at UCSF and have to cross the corner store to get to the hospital.   I just think it is unprofessional to sit with your shirt off outside the store you work.  I have also seen him in his undershirt sitting there....and the loaf of bread was several years previous when a lady ran it..
author: Mary V.

description: This neighborhood market is much more!! The coffee is handmade by cup...strong and delicious...excellent customer service and the owner makes you feel you are part of the family...I recommend it highly!
author: R. Scot S.

description: Sam made a deliciously smooth and full bodied cup of coffee.  He actually had me taste the grounds to prove that there was no bitterness in them.  He says it's all in the way he roasts the beans which come from Yemen.  Truly a special cup of coffee!
author: D M.

description:
pretty good sandwiches but prettier flowers. you can get a bigger and tastier sandwich at Yellow Submarine a block away, but Golden Bear has a grand selection of flowers . . . perfect for times you are trying to butter up your Mummy for forgetting her bday or her Valentine's gift. yes, I am obligated to gift my Mum for V-Day, ok. she did birth me, you know. and I was a breech, remember. and I did kick my way out of the Caesarian incision, nearly killing her on the spot. oh I'm divulging so much here. but it has been ingrained in me since birth.

ps: the Bear has a fine selection of fresh fruit too
author: Prima D.

description: Now there is a difference between excellent customer service and verbal harassment. These guys and one woman fall into the latter. When i have actually ventured inside (which was a grave mistake) i was almost bullied into buying some way overpriced speakeasy beer and then mocked for thinking i knew where to get it cheaper (anywhere!) so i walked down the street to the also somewhat shady and overpriced liquor store on 8th and Judah. One time i also went in for a sandwich which were about a 6 out of 10 for me and the guy making it didnt use gloves after coming in from moving boxes and produce outside, he tried to ham it up with me when i was ordering to mask the fact that it was taking him way too long to toast the bread. All in all this place sucks and the workers love to harass people in the store and on the street alike, avoid the corner this is on (6th and Judah) at all costs!
author: Sean B.

description: Great coffee! I like that it's made in the authentic Turkish style.
author: Michael J.

description: I can't believe the post that said Sam was sitting with his shirt off etc etc.  I visit this store nearly every day and Sam is always well-turned out and would never dream of lolling around shirtless!!!   Anyway, I love this place for all reasons and now he's doing coffee - the best I've had since coming here from Europe, straight, no-nonsense delicious coffee and his wife's pastries are fabulous.  There is also a comfy sofa inside to watch the comings and goings.
author: Poppy P.

description: Was up for the outside lands festival and stopped here for coffee before heading back to LA. This place is awesome and has the best coffee. If I lived close by i would be here every morning! Sam is the man!
author: Tyler U.

description: Started go to the Golden Bear about a month ago. I am no stranger to a good cup and this place is incredible. Sam makes an incredible brew. Took my wife and grandkids in today and had lunch, introducing everyone to him.  And the Baklava is awewsome as well.  Highly recommend this place to anyone who really wants an extraordinary cup of Turkish coffee.
author: Steve J.

description: They have just changed the format of the store and it now has really great prices on beer and has a few liquors at a great price too!  The coffee is still awesome and there is a nice place to enjoy a cup, a chat and a game of chess!
author: Deidre H.

description: I love turkish coffee so I was really happy to find this place one block from my brother's place on 5th avenue and Parnassus. Sam is a great guy and I enjoy the friendly banter about life, food, people, etc. Go and enjoy!
author: Paul W.

description:
I live close by and I am glad that there seems to be a consensus about that place - yes "that" place - don't go there unless you really need to! 

Updated 04/16/10 : Business has a big sign saying UNDER NEW MANAGEMENT ... 
They say more it changes more it stays the same...well, maybe not the same, instead of the less than pleasant lady we do have now a cheerful management belly-dancing and overly friendly with patrons or passers by... 
I know one thing for sure - not the best shopping place, that one, but surely a crazy place, it will amuse you at times or send out reasons of concerns at other times...
author: VIORICA C.

description: Reasonable selection of stuff for such a small store, but the owner kept trying to sell me stuff I didn't come in for.  Way to make me avoid shopping there unless I really have to.
author: GeekGirl X.

description: Whenever I get coffee from Sam it is the highlight of my day. It is always delicious and the service is second to none!
author: Jeremy W.

description: I paid twice the price for 1 gallon crystal spring water when compared to that at AL's market nearby. And the only reason i went there was because it's closer. The selections in the store look mostly old and rustic and I'd not want to stop by again unless needed.
author: Elle W.

description: The lady tried to get me to loan her a dollar the first time I shopped there. But the beer was extremely cold. Then yesterday she charged me $4.50 for a big Sapporro that was extremely cold. Kind of more hassle than it's worth, unless you need your beer extremely cold.
author: Jonny A.

description: My boyrfriend and I stumbled into Sam's (not knowing who Sam was) yesterday after a massage on Irving.  Our recommendation:  If you haven't been, GO.  Go meet Sam (he will strike up a conversation), have him make you a turkey sandwich on wheat, and don't leave without trying the coffee and pistachio bahklava. Sam, we will be back!
author: Erica W.

description: Great flowers.  Too small for my purposes, but I will tell you I love corner stores, and this one definitely has its charm.  The flowers out front always make me smile.  Never met the lady, but the stories I have heard have been funny or interesting.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
Items are WAY overpriced and old, plus this lady is crazy and stale!

She gossips about everyone in the neighborhood and expects her neighbors to do favors for her after overcharging them, like driving her at 11pm!

If you go in there, she will bully-you into paying too much for something you don't even want and keep you there for at least 15 minutes chatting absolute nonsense! If you just pass by, she'll harass you into purchasing a sandwich, or some flowers, or something! Otherwise, you're "wasting my time".  

If you dare cross her once, she will bite your butt off and tell the whole neighborhood about how bad of a person you are, but will try to be nice after you boycott her store and try to get you to buy from her again.

I'm still boycotting her store, and I'm so much happier, even if I have to walk a few extra blocks to get my ice cream & beer fix!
author: Chitz C.

description:
i have lived on 8th and Irving for over 2 years now.  i am a student at UCSF and have to walk past this "establishment" every day, not once but twice.

strange things go on here.  most often, i hear yelling.  and i'm talking loud, domestic dispute yelling.  sometimes the crazy old lady is yelling at the phone, sometimes at her husband (?), soemtimes at someone else in the shop.  scary.

i have only brought myself into that store 2 times in all the time i've lived here.  the first time was over 2 years ago and i vowed NEVER EVER EVER to go back.  i don't remember all the details but I remember getting my item and standing at the counter for literally 5 minutes while the crazy old lady chatted up someone behind the sandwich counter.  periodically she would look over at me and then keep talking.  i finally just left without buying anything.  

the second time was just this morning. Monday morning with a loooong weekend (oops, too much fun) past me and a long day ahead of me....i needed a coke to wake up (not a coffee drinker).  i thought how harmless it would be to grab a simple can of coke from there.  wrong.  transcript of our conversation:

crazy old lady: "good morning!"
me: "good morning, how are you?"  put my coke down on the counter.  "how much is it?"
COL: "one dollar."
me: pulls out a $20.  "ok great."
COL: eyeballing my wallet. "You don't have any change?"
me: feeling weird.  "No.  If i had it, I would've given it to you."  awkward moment as I'm still holding the $20 out to her and she is still staring at my wallet.  cue tumbleweed.
me: "ok that's ok.  i can go somewhere else."
COL: "good bye."  grabs the coke can.
me: on my way out.  "I don't think I'll ever shop here again."
COL: "I don't care!"
me: OBVIOUSLY!

i walk past here twice a day at minimum, but average 4 times per day (because I go home for lunch).  the place is always empty.  does she really not understand the concept of customer service?  it boggles my mind...
author: gail g.

description: wondered into this market by accident, and so glad I did! the owner is quite the character! he told me that if I tried his coffee and didn't like it he would give me the bottle of wine I had every day for a month! I was so intrigued that I brought some friends in later that day. great coffee, great baklava and a superb experience. What a wonderful man. Only caution I have is you can't go in if you don;t have time to spare. He likes to chat!
author: Amy F.

description: I have had a series of strange interactions with the old woman who works here. I came in with my pregnant friend (who had chosen not to find out the sex of her baby) and this woman says "Is a boy... this my gift to you." Oddly enough she turned out to be right- not that my friend had the intention of knowing. And then there's yesterday. Fresh out of a procedure at UCSF hospital all I wanted was a 6 pack of Fat Tire, and Golden Bear is on my way home. When i get to the counter, she proceeds to pack the beer in a crumpled up used bag, and then I try to hand her my ID. She barely looks at it, looks at me and says "no, i won't sell you the beer." On a previous occasion of beer buying she stared at my ID counting on her fingers, and I had to help her do the math to make sense of the fact that I am in fact 21 before overcharging me a ridiculous amount for it. Yesterday seriously irritated me, she flat out refused to sell me beer because she was unable to do simple math to figure out my age, apparently she thought that her powers of age deduction were more accurate then my California Drivers license. Well to avoid the hassle I will walk a couple blocks further out of my way to Roxy... bummer and bad for Golden Bear's business to lose customers because of something so basic and stupid.
author: Margot K.

description: this place is the coolest spot to kick it if ur in the sunset and need a place to chill.The guy working hooked me up with the best coffee and the most ridiculous sense of humor. plus he let me take his photo and then exclaimed it was the best photo I'll ever take bc he was in it. love it.
author: Lillian S.
